Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Type 1: FRABJOUS CS - Framing a Rigourous Approach to Beauty and Joy for Outreach to Underrepresented Students in Computing at Scale

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of California, Berkeley and the University of North Carolina, Charlotte propose a collaborative effort, called FRABJOUS, to develop and deploy a proposed, new Advanced Placement (AP) computing course that can successfully achieve outreach -- attracting women and underrepresented minorities -- while having a technically rigorous programming component. The work extends the PIs' previous work on the Berkeley "Beauty and Joy of Computing" course and the College Board's CS Principles course to the high school level, addressing the development and study of new instructional materials as well as the impact of teacher professional development on student learning outcomes. The course uses a visually rich programming environment, called Snap, that is based on Scratch. Scratch has had well-documented success in teaching computer programming to 8-14 year olds because of the power of its visual metaphor. Snap extends the metaphor to teach more advanced methods, including recursion, higher order procedures, and object-oriented programming, to 14-19 year olds. Specifically the FRABJOUS project will

. Develop a core group of mentor teachers in the Berkeley and Charlotte areas,
. Conduct and evaluate intensive summer professional development workshops for in-service high school teachers,
. Develop regional partnerships between universities and high schools, creating CSTA chapters and connecting them through the STARS Alliance,
. Study university and high school student learning outcomes, disaggregating data by race, gender, age, course, and curricular models to understand the curriculum's effectiveness, ease of use, and impact, particularly the introduction of advanced concepts (higher order functions, recursion,
distributed computing, concurrency, simulation) at this early level,
. Compare outcomes for students and teaches trained directly by the PIs with those trained by the mentor teachers, and
. Expand the capability of Snap.

The project thus includes tool and materials development, assessments of student learning outcomes, and study of the impact of teacher professional development via workshops and school year support activities, including peer-to-peer and online support.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF and the College Board started the CS Principles project to broaden participation in computer science by making the field more attractive to women and underrepresented minorities. Their key insight is that young people in all demographic groups love computers, in the form of social networking, cell phones, and video games. It’s computer programming that has the bad stereotype among young people. They therefore designed a curriculum framework in which programming is just one of seven broad topic areas, anchored in the social setting in which computers are used. The University of California, Berkeley developed The Beauty and Joy of Computing (BJC) to be a version of CS Principles that would deepen students’ understanding by putting more emphasis on programming than the framework requires; we agree with the CS Principles insight about meeting students where they are, but we feel that the job isn’t done unless, by the end of the course, the students have experienced programming itself as beautiful and enjoyable. Computer science—often seen as uninteresting and inaccessible to all but the brilliant—is, in fact, beautiful, learnable, empowering, and accessible to a very broad range of students.

The success of the course at UC Berkeley—particularly with non-computer science majors—attracted high school computer science teachers who wanted to offer their students a similar introductory experience. Many early-adopting high school teachers opted into summer teacher professional development for BJC in California, North Carolina, and elsewhere.

Through this NSF-funded work, UCB continued its development of the BJC curriculum and the Snap! visual programming language that supports it, developed regional partnerships with universities and high schools, offered teacher preparation workshops that reached over 200 high school teachers, began analysis on data collected about learning outcomes, and began training a core group of workshop-leading facilitators. The entire original BJC curriculum developed through this work, including lecture videos, online lab exercises, and course readings, is made available online free of charge on the UCB BJC website [UC Berkeley, 2017]. We also spent years developing an edX massive open online course (MOOC) to allow teachers to enroll high school students and facilitate course adoption. [UC Berkeley, 2016].

Data analyses show gains by both teachers and students from their interactions with the BJC curriculum. Most students surveyed (81%, N=257) indicated that they would recommend the course. Teachers surveyed (N=37) showed gains in: content (e.g., Snap! programming including recursion), preparation (e.g., providing enrichment for gifted students), and equity (e.g., integrating principles of social justice into instruction). Teacher content outcomes were correlated with prior content experience and equity outcomes related to pre-test scores and K–12 teaching experience.

Results were disseminated through workshops and research papers at several international computer science education venues: the Special Interest Group in Computer Science Education (SIGCSE), International Computing Education Research (ICER), Scratch and Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) annual conferences, to name a few. Also, two magazine articles about BJC were published in the Association of Computing Machinery (ACM) computer science education magazine, Inroads [Garcia et al, 2012 & 2015]. Follow-up support occurred through local 1­-day CSTA professional development events, and through the “BJC TEACHERS” Piazza online forum, which currently has over six hundred fifty members.

This project, along with all “CS for All” professional development NSF-funded projects, aims to broaden participation in computing, for students who may become majors or may not. Those not in computing-related fields will gain a balanced perspective of the limits of computing, and the hidden and unintended consequences of technology. They will also be empowered to be able to write a program in case they have a personal or professional interest. Those who decide to major in computing will be the ones who will be making the apps, services and interactive technologies that will define our ever-reliant-to-technology society of the future, impacting all Americans.
